text:
This  report  details  exploration  carried  out  on  the  Westbrook  tenement  E31/571  during  the 
 reporting  period  8/01/2005  to  7/01/2006.  Jackson  Gold  is  the  beneficial  and/or  registered 
 holder of the tenements. 
 Exploration  licence  31/571  is  located  on  Edjudina  Station,  approximately  150  km  NE  from 
 Kalgoorlie  along  the  Yarri  Road  to  the  Edjudina  Homestead  turnoff  and  then  south  of  the 
 homestead via station tracks (Figure 1).  The Project is located within the Edjudina Region in 
 the Laverton Tectonic Zone, centrally between Kalgoorlie and Laverton.  
 The  Westbrook  tenement  was  part  of  a  farm-in  agreement  between  Jackson  Gold  Ltd  and 
 Quantum Resources Ltd. The terms of the agreement allow for Jackson Gold Ltd to earn 80% 
 interest  in  the  tenement  by  meeting  the  DoIR  expenditure  requirements  for  3  years  after 
 granting of the lease. Furthermore Jackson Gold have agreed to expend a minimum of $30,000 
 in  the  first  year  of  granting  E31/571.  Quantum  Resource  Ltd  will  retain  20%  interest  free 
 carried to decision to mine. Jackson Gold Ltd are managing the Westbrook tenement.  
 The Westbrook Project occurs within the Norseman - Wiluna Archaean Greenstone belt in the 
 Eastern Goldfields province of the Yilgarn Craton. The Project is located within the Edjudina 
 Region  in  the  Laverton  Tectonic  Zone,  centrally  between  Kalgoorlie  and  Laverton.  The 
 Edjudina  Terrane  is  bounded  by  the  Claypan  Fault  and  the  Pinjin  Fault.  The  Terrane  is 
 dominated by calc-alkaline, andesitic volcanic complexes and their epiclastic debris with only 
 minor  volumes  of  tholeiitic  basalt  and  komatiite  (Swager,  1995).  The  Westbrook  tenement 
 straddles  the  boundary  between  the  sediment  dominated  terrane  to  the  west  and  the 
 predominantly  mafic  lithologies  to  the  east.    The  dominant  lithological  feature  within  the 
 tenement  is  the  Wallbrook  Hill  chert  horizon,  which  outcrops  intermittently  throughout  the 
 project  area.  Structurally,  the  tenement  lies  in  a  favourable  location,  with  a  number  of  soil 
 anomalies identified from first pass sampling.  
 Exploration activities included auger drilling, regolith mapping and geochemical processing of 
 surface sample data (Figure 2).

50.text: The Westbrook Project occurs within the Norseman - Wiluna Archaean Greenstone belt in the

51.text: Eastern Goldfields province of the Yilgarn Craton. The Project is located within the Edjudina

52.text: Region in the Laverton Tectonic Zone, centrally between Kalgoorlie and Laverton (Figure 3).

54.text: The granite-greenstone belt is approximately 600 kilometres in length, and is characterised by

55.text: thick, possibly rift-controlled, accumulations of ultramafic, mafic, felsic volcanic, intrusives

56.text: and sedimentary rocks.  Greenstone successions of the southern Eastern Goldfields have been

57.text: segregated  into  elongate  structural  terranes  bounded  by  regional  NNW-trending  faults

58.text: (Swager, 1995).  These terranes include the Kalgoorlie Terrane, Gindalbie Terrane, Kurnalpi

59.text: Terrane and the Edjudina Terrane. These terrains contain distinct similarities, including timing

60.text: of the deposition of volcano-sedimentary sequences (2720-2675 Ma) and regional deformation

61.text: and plutonism (2675-2620 Ma). The terrains differ only in lithostratigraphic development and

64.text: The Edjudina Terrane is bounded by the Claypan Fault and the Pinjin Fault. The Terrane is

65.text: dominated by calc-alkaline, andesitic volcanic complexes and their epiclastic debris with only

 The Westbrook Project occurs within the Norseman - Wiluna Archaean Greenstone belt in the 
 Eastern Goldfields province of the Yilgarn Craton. The Project is located within the Edjudina 
 Region in the Laverton Tectonic Zone, centrally between Kalgoorlie and Laverton (Figure 3). 
 The granite-greenstone belt is approximately 600 kilometres in length, and is characterised by 
 thick, possibly rift-controlled, accumulations of ultramafic, mafic, felsic volcanic, intrusives 
 and sedimentary rocks.  Greenstone successions of the southern Eastern Goldfields have been 
 segregated  into  elongate  structural  terranes  bounded  by  regional  NNW-trending  faults 
 (Swager, 1995).  These terranes include the Kalgoorlie Terrane, Gindalbie Terrane, Kurnalpi 
 Terrane and the Edjudina Terrane. These terrains contain distinct similarities, including timing 
 of the deposition of volcano-sedimentary sequences (2720-2675 Ma) and regional deformation 
 and plutonism (2675-2620 Ma). The terrains differ only in lithostratigraphic development and 
 early tectonic history (Swager, 1995). 
 The Edjudina Terrane is bounded by the Claypan Fault and the Pinjin Fault. The Terrane is 
 dominated by calc-alkaline, andesitic volcanic complexes and their epiclastic debris with only 
 minor volumes of tholeiitic basalt and komatiite (Swager, 1995).

8.text: The Westbrook tenement is located 7km due south of the Porphyry Mining Centre and 3km

9.text: north-west of Jackson Gold’s Eleven Bells and Redbrook Projects.

11.text: The Porphyry and Million Dollar deposits occur within two 20o - 25o east-dipping shear zones

12.text: within  the  Porphyry  Quartz  Monzonite.  The  Porphyry  shear  zone,  which  cuts  the  eastern

13.text: margin  of  the  intrusion,  is  approximately  25m  wide.  Gold  is  localized  in  a  series  of  en

14.text: echeolon lenses, with the highest grades contained within mylonitic zones about 10cm thick

15.text: (Swager, 1995). The alteration mineralogy is quartz-muscovite-pyrite, and probably includes

16.text: fine-grained hematite produced at a late stage of mineralisation. The low-grade Million Dollar

17.text: mineralized shear occurs some 350 m above the Porphyry shear and two kilometres south of

20.text: Competency  contrast  is  considered  important  in  localising  mineralised  vein  systems  at  the

21.text: Wallbrook deposit (Roberts, F.I., 2000). At Wallbrook a mineralised quartz vein stockwork

22.text: has developed within a small syenogranitic intrusion within metabasalt. Locally however, the

23.text: wallrocks at Wallbrook comprise relatively incompetent felsic schists. Quartz veins formed a

24.text: conjugate set while the local principal stress axis was orientated northeast – southwest.

28.text: From the Landsat TM Image it would appear that the surfical cover over E31/571 is generally

29.text: of  a  residual  nature,  except  in  the  vicinity  of  the  drainage  features  where  the  regolith  is

30.text: depositional. The regolith in the area is shown in the Landsat TM Image (Figure 4).

36.text: It is evident from the regional aeromagnetic data that the majority of the structures trend in a

37.text: northwest  direction,  parallel  to  stratigraphy  (Figure  5.)  The  low  angle  regional  shear  zones

38.text: bound or truncate lithologic – stratigraphic packages.

text:
The Westbrook tenement is located 7km due south of the Porphyry Mining Centre and 3km 
 north-west of Jackson Gold’s Eleven Bells and Redbrook Projects. 
 The Porphyry and Million Dollar deposits occur within two 20o - 25o east-dipping shear zones 
 within  the  Porphyry  Quartz  Monzonite.  The  Porphyry  shear  zone,  which  cuts  the  eastern 
 margin  of  the  intrusion,  is  approximately  25m  wide.  Gold  is  localized  in  a  series  of  en 
 echeolon lenses, with the highest grades contained within mylonitic zones about 10cm thick 
 (Swager, 1995). The alteration mineralogy is quartz-muscovite-pyrite, and probably includes 
 fine-grained hematite produced at a late stage of mineralisation. The low-grade Million Dollar 
 mineralized shear occurs some 350 m above the Porphyry shear and two kilometres south of 
 Competency  contrast  is  considered  important  in  localising  mineralised  vein  systems  at  the 
 Wallbrook deposit (Roberts, F.I., 2000). At Wallbrook a mineralised quartz vein stockwork 
 has developed within a small syenogranitic intrusion within metabasalt. Locally however, the 
 wallrocks at Wallbrook comprise relatively incompetent felsic schists. Quartz veins formed a 
 conjugate set while the local principal stress axis was orientated northeast – southwest. 
 From the Landsat TM Image it would appear that the surfical cover over E31/571 is generally 
 of  a  residual  nature,  except  in  the  vicinity  of  the  drainage  features  where  the  regolith  is 
 depositional. The regolith in the area is shown in the Landsat TM Image (Figure 4).   
 It is evident from the regional aeromagnetic data that the majority of the structures trend in a 
 northwest  direction,  parallel  to  stratigraphy  (Figure  5.)  The  low  angle  regional  shear  zones 
 bound or truncate lithologic – stratigraphic packages.  
 The post-regional folding granitoids are clearly evident in the aeromagnetic data from their

text:
The Westbrook tenement straddles the boundary between the sediment dominated terrane to 
 the west and the predominantly mafic lithologies to the east. The dominant lithological feature 
 within  the  tenement  is  the  Wallbrook  Hill  chert  horizon,  which  outcrops  intermittently 
 throughout  the  project  area.  Structurally,  the  tenement  lies  in  a  favourable  location,  with  a 
 number of soil anomalies identified from first pass sampling.

39.text: The Westbrook Project falls with previous explorer, New Consolidated Gold Fields’ nickel-

40.text: copper exploration area. The focus of their exploration was to test all ultramafic contacts for

41.text: mineralisation. No sulphide mineralisation was detected although a small deposit of lateritic

42.text: nickel was located. This deposit was considered to be of sub-economic size and value.

49.text: Asarco  Australia  undertook  exploration  for  copper  and  zinc  over  an  area  which  included

50.text: tenement  E31/571.  Exploration  activities  included  geological  mapping,  rockchip  and  soil

51.text: sampling and RAB drilling. It was concluded that no significant copper -zinc mineralization or

52.text: alteration was logged in the drill chips.

60.text: The northern half of E31/571 falls into the historical Welsh Find copper-zinc/gold exploration

61.text: project area. Exploration for volcanogenic copper-zinc massive suphides in alluvium-covered,

62.text: quartz –veined Archaean felsic volcanics did not identify any encouraging base-metal targets.

63.text: Assessment  of  low  grade  gold  potential,  repetitions  of  the  Porphyry  and  Million  Dollar

64.text: mineralisation  identified  a  wide  pyritic  and  hematitic  mineralised  mylonitic  shear  zone  in

65.text: syenite porphyry with a best intersection of 4m @ 3.2 g/t Au. The mineralisation within the

66.text: alteration  envelope  appeared  to  be  erratically  distributed  with  no  continuous  body  of

gold mineralisation were tested or field checked with negative results. 
 Lake Rebecca nickel – copper exploration 
 New Consolidated Gold Fields Aust Ltd 
 1966- 1971 
 The Westbrook Project falls with previous explorer, New Consolidated Gold Fields’ nickel-
 copper exploration area. The focus of their exploration was to test all ultramafic contacts for 
 mineralisation. No sulphide mineralisation was detected although a small deposit of lateritic 
 nickel was located. This deposit was considered to be of sub-economic size and value. 
 Mount Wallbrook copper-zinc exploration 
 Asarco Australia Ltd 
 1976- 1978 
 Asarco  Australia  undertook  exploration  for  copper  and  zinc  over  an  area  which  included 
 tenement  E31/571.  Exploration  activities  included  geological  mapping,  rockchip  and  soil 
 sampling and RAB drilling. It was concluded that no significant copper -zinc mineralization or 
 alteration was logged in the drill chips.   
 Welsh Find copper-zinc/gold exploration 
 Australian Selection PtyLtd 
 Seltrust Mining Corp Pty Ltd 
 1978- 1981 
 The northern half of E31/571 falls into the historical Welsh Find copper-zinc/gold exploration 
 project area. Exploration for volcanogenic copper-zinc massive suphides in alluvium-covered, 
 quartz –veined Archaean felsic volcanics did not identify any encouraging base-metal targets. 
 Assessment  of  low  grade  gold  potential,  repetitions  of  the  Porphyry  and  Million  Dollar  
 mineralisation  identified  a  wide  pyritic  and  hematitic  mineralised  mylonitic  shear  zone  in 
 syenite porphyry with a best intersection of 4m @ 3.2 g/t Au. The mineralisation within the 
 alteration  envelope  appeared  to  be  erratically  distributed  with  no  continuous  body  of

7.text: first pass soil sampling identified a number of soil anomalies.

of  previous  exploration,  WAMEX  open  file  data  compilation,  processing  of  regional

 A total of 206 soil samples were taken to cover the major portion of tenement E31/571. This 
 first pass soil sampling identified a number of soil anomalies.

15.text: A pedogenic carbonate auger drilling programme comprising 79 holes was conducted during

16.text: the  reporting  period.  The  auger  holes  were  drilled  to  a  depth  of  0.5m  and  drilling  was

17.text: conducted over the northern half and the south-east corner of E31/571. Drillhole locations are

18.text: presented  in  Figure  6.    Digital  data  for  the  drilling  programme  including  hole  collars  and

19.text: assays is presented in the drilling file in Appendix 1.

21.text: The  samples  were  submitted  to  Amdel  Laboratories  for  the  analysis  of  Au  (1ppb),  As

22.text: (0.5ppm), Bi (0.1ppm), Ca (5ppm), Fe (100ppm), Mn (5ppm), Mo (0.1ppm), Pb (0.2ppm) and

23.text: Sb (0.1 ppm) using an aqua regia digest and an atomic absorption spectroscopy finish.

25.text: Three holes in the north-west corner returned anomalous gold values of 17 ppb, 17 ppb and 19

text:
A pedogenic carbonate auger drilling programme comprising 79 holes was conducted during 
 the  reporting  period.  The  auger  holes  were  drilled  to  a  depth  of  0.5m  and  drilling  was 
 conducted over the northern half and the south-east corner of E31/571. Drillhole locations are 
 presented  in  Figure  6.    Digital  data  for  the  drilling  programme  including  hole  collars  and 
 assays is presented in the drilling file in Appendix 1.  
 The  samples  were  submitted  to  Amdel  Laboratories  for  the  analysis  of  Au  (1ppb),  As 
 (0.5ppm), Bi (0.1ppm), Ca (5ppm), Fe (100ppm), Mn (5ppm), Mo (0.1ppm), Pb (0.2ppm) and 
 Sb (0.1 ppm) using an aqua regia digest and an atomic absorption spectroscopy finish.  
 Three holes in the north-west corner returned anomalous gold values of 17 ppb, 17 ppb and 19

43.text: different sample media, sampling methods, digestion and analytical techniques and laboratory

thresholds  commonly  causes  ‘edge  effects’  that  can  obscure  real  data  trends.  Levelling 
 involves a statistical manipulation of the data so as to minimize batch effects which include 
 different sample media, sampling methods, digestion and analytical techniques and laboratory 
 batch results. Levelling of the data generated several new trends and anomalies and in some
